Message.Msg: Already a member since 2006,

Energy policies Bush: Pro drilling in the Arctic National Wildlife Refuge, California, and all everywhere else there is cheap oil. Pro clean coal. Pro natural gas. Pro hydrogen economy and nano-tech and Federal research to develop it. Pro invasion of OPEC countries (like Iraq) to secure more oil supplies. Obama: Supposedly pro oil drilling but only in the most expensive areas with small fields and high cost oil. Anti- coal. Anti- cheap natural gas. Seems more interested in the Federal aspect of forced investment than the economics of cheap energy. In favor of military campaigns in countries with no oil (Afghanistan) and against maintaining American control over with large amounts of oil (Iraq). Against invading other countries with large oil fields (Libya) and allowing other countries (or local terrorist groups) to control the resources. Romney: His energy policy will be much like Bush. On most important single issue there is no resemblance between the three. Perhaps on peripheral issues of little relevance there is common ground...

Message.Title: War On Energy
Message.Msg: The Democrats have been on a campaign against it ever since the Kyoto Treaty was signed in 1997. They elected Gore as their nominee in 2000 because of his radical environmental agenda. Gore lost but the Democrats of his ilk in Congress kept up the fight. They managed to block Bush's energy policy, soon after he was elected, contributing to the oil price spike and the housing and financial crash that was a direct result of it. The election of Obama has escalated the conflict to new heights. Not only has Obama obstructed oil drilling in every cheap high yielding place he can manage, he has also blocked pipeline transportation to import cheap Canadian tar sands oil. Obama's EPA has launched endless regulatory assaults on the utilities and power plants. Their latest unconstitutional assault was shot down in the courts, but if Obama wins another term this promises to be only a temporary set back for his radical agenda. An Obama victory will cement America's fate. It's growth trajectory, which was built on cheap energy for the past 400 years, will come to an end.

Message.Title: 60 votes in Senate
Message.Msg: The Senate is what will matter going forward + the White House. It will require 60 votes in the Senate to defeat the Democrat's environmental agenda and open up Alaska, the outer continental shelf, and all other Federal lands to oil drilling. Licensing of coal plants, and new heavy oil refineries, and repeal of the EPA's air quality regulations, will require 60 votes as well. The economy will not recover until American energy supplies are opened up fully to development. It is insufficient to control the White House as Bush proved. As for the phony economy built on debt, low interest rates, and inflated stock prices - that will deflate and push unemployment even higher when it does.

During the 1990s the economy of Eastern Europe and Russia collapsed due to the unraveling of the Communist economic system, which reduced oil demand in the former Warsaw Pact countries by nearly 3 million barrels per day. The United States and European economic profited handsomely from the collapsing oil prices caused by the gusher oil from those areas on the world market. Clinton had nothing to do with that; indeed his party actively undermined the Reagan arms buildup that helped to usher it in. Bush never had a chance to implement his energy policy because of Democrat obstruction in the Senate. The President cannot make law and getting laws passed without 60 votes in the Senate is effectively impossible. By the 2000s the former Warsaw Pact countries' economy was on the mend, and China's economy was surging ahead on the back of a major road building campaign. Oil demand rocketed up and thanks to Democrat obstruction of oil drilling in America the demand could not be met except after a 1000% increase in oil prices. That price increase caused the financial crisis. The ultimate solution to this fundamental supply/demand imbalance in the oil market will be the invasion of more OPEC countries to open up the supply sources they are manipulating to keep prices up. The United States has the power to do this if it chooses. It may well require nuclear weapons, to demonstrate the resolve of the United States to put an end to oil cartels and dictators obstructing market forces...

The Warsaw Pact in 1990, ex-East Germany, consisted of the Soviet Union, Hungary, Romania, Poland, Czechoslovakia, and Bulgaria. Its combined oil demand was 9,716,000 barrels per day. By 1999 its combined oil demand was down to 4,478,000 barrels per day, a drop of 5,238,000 barrels per day. The economic recovery of Clinton's first term was marked by the first 3 million barrel drop in former Warsaw Pact oil demand, and the second term extended it. http://www.eia.gov/cfapps/ipdbproject/iedindex3.cfm?tid=5&pid=5&aid=2&cid=regions&syid=1990&eyid=2009&unit=TBPD As for 60 votes. It takes only 40 to do nothing, which is what Clinton's energy policy consisted of. He could get by with that because of the collapse of the Soviet Union's economy and the torrent of cheap oil issuing from it. It takes 60 votes to do something, hence Bush's difficulties in increasing oil supplies.

"Those of us that pray for peace do not include the egomaniacal example of perennial tyrannical bullies that typify much of the Middle East." "The first way to lose your state is to neglect the art of war; the first way to win a state is to be skilled in the art of war." - Niccolo Machiavelli Wars are expensive and dangerous solutions to problems as Machiavelli teaches. Ignoring enemies and giving them time to plot does not diminish their threat; on the contrary, it increases the threat with each passing day. A Prince should be mindful of the threats his enemies present, and take forceful action against them. Obama has ignored the threats and allowed them to festered to monstrous proportions. The solution will be even more monstrous, but quite necessary none-the-less. Bush's policies were not conducted according to sound Machiavellian policy either. The main difficulty was he did not understand you cannot win the hearts and minds of your enemy. Also did not want to hear what it would take to achieve his aims. Warmonger by chicken hawks is not good policy. It takes a firm hand at the wheel of the Ship of State to avoid devastating wars. "The first way to lose your state is to neglect the art of war; the first way to win a state is to be skilled in the art of war." Is it really 600 years? I thought it was only 60 years, where right-wingers are stuck in the past.... the 'white picket fence' stupidity.

"In times of societal collapse, which Republicans still see as an option, despite centuries of societal stability (post 1506) within a system of legal recourse." You either do not know the history since 1506 or you are deliberately misrepresenting it to make another irrelevant conclusion. Try opening an excel spreadsheet and saving it as "war." Next list all the wars from 1506 to 2012 and which states were involved, and their expense. You should be able to see quite clearly a pattern of increasing military activity. This may be surprising to you, but it was no mystery to people like Machiavelli, but the states that were most skillful at war developed strong societies, superior legal structures, and ended up better off than their weaker more passive neighbors. Developing a state is important, too. There is a difference between a powerful state and a powerful monarchy. Skill in war is acquired by experience, not by theory or books. One more quote from Machiavelli: "The main foundations of every state, new states as well as ancient or composite ones, are good laws and good arms; and because you cannot have good laws without good arms, and where there are good arms, good laws inevitably follow, I shall not discuss the laws but the arms." You are a poor philosopher LC, and certainly no match for the like of Machiavelli. His statement above predicts perfectly the development of the superior legal, economic, and military state of Great Britain, France, and the United States, Germany, and many others. The hapless Oriental states just couldn't keep up... Believe whatever you want about the modern world, but keep in mind your attitude is not supported by history; indeed it is flat out contradicted by it. Your attitude is one of denial mixed with ignorance - a pathetic combination.

btw., the relevancy is to conduct war, not how it is conducted, you war monger. If inevitable (last resort), so be it. BUT..... Last resort, originating as "Just War", I believe, has been modernized many times with the Convention Hague 1907 etc., but no better has the description on its use been said by Jackson; "We must make clear to the Germans that the wrong for which their fallen leaders are on trial is not that they lost the war, but that they started it. And we must not allow ourselves to be drawn into a trial of the causes of the war, for our position is that no grievances or policies will justify resort to aggressive war. It is utterly renounced and condemned as an instrument of policy." Republican have show, even up to this decade, that they hold these words in contempt.

To conduct war or not conduct it is relevant to the health of the state, laws, institutions, and their advancement. The conduct of war speaks to the efficacy of war as a tool of policy. Both are well explained by Machiavelli. Both points can easily be backed up by endless historical examples. Bush's failure to accomplish anything useful in Iraq could be expected, as could Obama's failure in Afghanistan. It should be noted too that America failed to get results in Vietnam until Nixon launched Operation Linebacker II. The attitude of his enemy instantly improved, just as could be expected. The Hague Convention is off topic. That speaks again to your theory of peace and harmony which you have yet to support with any evidence.
